newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU mulls rules on Internet phone calls.
newsitem.headline: EU mulls rules on Internet phone calls.

text.p: The European Commission, eager to create a level playing field for businesses, sought comments on Tuesday on whether it should propose legislation on telephone calls carried on the Internet.

It said in a statement that such calls did not appear to fall under existing rules on voice telephony, which require filing for operating licences, but needed to be studied in the light of the full liberalisation of the EU's telecoms market in 1998.

"The idea is not to push them (Internet phone service providers) into a straightjacket but we want to make sure that normal conditions (apply) to everyone on the market place," the spokesman for European Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert said.

Thanks to fast-developing information technology, companies and individuals can already speak to each other through the Internet computer online network provided the computers are equipped with microphones.

Such service, developed in particular by U.S. software maker Netscape Communications Corp, is making traditional phone companies increasingly nervous about competition from other companies which are not subject to the same rules.

The Commission said it would soon publish a notice in the EU's Official Journal and on its Internet site (EUROPA.EU.INT) requesting all interested parties to submit their views within a period of two months.

It said it planned to adopt a "flexible legal framework adaptable to the technological evolution in the sector taking into account, in particular, the innovative aspects of multimedia phone services".

The EU will complete on January 1, 1998 the opening of the European telecoms market to competition by ending a voice telephony monopoly still enjoyed by most national phone operators. The mobile phone business has already been liberalised.
